{{Infobox writer | name = Michael Smith | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = M F Smith, Mike Smith, Professor Mike Smith | birth_name = Michael F Smith | birth_date = 1948<!-- Use when full details found {{Birth date and age|1960|mm|dd}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = Computer scientist, businessman | language = English | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = British | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = | subject = IT, software prototyping, health informatics | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|youthinmind.com}}{{URL|fm2x.com}}{{URL|sdqscore.org}} | portaldisp = }} '''Michael F Smith''' (born 1948) is a [[computer scientist]], [[health informatics|medical informatician]] and businessman living in London. He specializes in [[software prototyping]],<ref>''Software Prototyping: Adoption, Practice and Management''. McGraw-Hill, London (1991).{{page needed|date=August 2018 | pages=200}}</ref> [[computer security]],<ref>Smith MF. Computer safety in medicine and patient identification. High Integrity Systems Journal 1995;1(4):397-398. ISSN 0967-2648.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.308.6929.612 |pmid=8148706 |pmc=2539746 |title=Are clinical information systems safe? |journal=BMJ |volume=308 |issue=6929 |pages=612 |year=1994 |last1=Smith |first1=M F }}</ref> non-cryptocurrency [[blockchain]] <ref>Sharing Ledgers For Sharing Economies: An Exploration Of Mutual Distributed Ledgers (aka blockchain technology), ''Journal of Financial Perspectives'', Volume 3, Number 3, EY Global Financial Services Institute, December 2015 (with [[Michael Mainelli]]). http://www.zyen.com/Articles/Journal%20of%20Financial%20Perspectives%20-%20Sharing%20Ledgers%20for%20Sharing%20Economie....pdf</ref> and [[health informatics]],<ref>''Computer Systems in Healthcare: Management and Strategy''. Kindle (2012).{{page needed|date=August 2018}}</ref> especially in [[mental health informatics|mental health]] systems.
== Biography == Smith worked in [[Dublin]] and [[Geneva]] from 1976 to 1980 developing petroleum information systems for [[Petroconsultants]] SA. During that time, he also developed microprocessor based oceanographic instruments at [[University College Galway]] and was awarded a DPhil. He was appointed lecturer in computer science at [[Reading University]] in 1980 and became head of R&D for [[ISTEL]], the computing company of the [[Rover Group]] in 1984.
Smith held several directorial positions in the petroleum industry and management consultancy until 1990 when he was appointed Professor of [[Health Informatics]] at [[Keele University]] in the departments of Medicine and Computer Science; he also concurrently held the position of Director of Information for [[List of NHS Health Authorities (1996–2002)|North Staffordshire Health Authority]]. In 1996, he moved to London and held professorial posts at [[City University London|City University]], [[St Bartholomew's Hospital|Barts]], [[London School of Economics and Political Science|LSE]] and [[University College London|UCL]] and managerial positions at [[Z/Yen]] and [[PwC]]. In 2000, he founded [[Medix UK Limited]]<ref>Smith MF. Internet facilitates in situ survey research of practising clinicians. Pharmaceutical Visions 2001; (Summer):48-52. ISSN 0966-1719.</ref> and fm2x limited<ref>http://fm2x.com</ref> in 2007. He retired from active academic life in 2008. Currently, Smith is involved mainly in the development of large-scale, highly secure web-based clinical systems and non-currency [[blockchain]] technology. He is a long term collaborator with [[Robert N. Goodman|Professor Robert Goodman]], developing online [[Mental health informatics|psychiatric screening systems]], such as the SDQ [[Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire]] and DAWBA.
==Publications== Some other publications: * "'Confidentiality, Privacy and Safety of Healthcare Systems". Special edition of ''Health Informatics Journal'', December 1998 (with [[Ross J. Anderson]]). *{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/146045829800400302 |title=Privacy, Confidentiality and Safety of Healthcare Information Systems: Better Information is Needed |journal=Health Informatics Journal |volume=4 |issue=3–4 |pages=124–127 |year=2016 |last1=Smith |first1=M. F }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.312.7025.197 |pmid=8563575 |pmc=2349993 |title=Data protection, health care, and the new European directive |journal=BMJ |volume=312 |issue=7025 |pages=197–198 |year=1996 |last1=Smith |first1=M F }} * "Computer safety in medicine and patient identification". ''High Integrity Systems Journal'' 1995;1(4):397-398. *{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.308.6929.612 |pmid=8148706 |pmc=2539746 |title=Are clinical information systems safe? |journal=BMJ |volume=308 |issue=6929 |pages=612 |year=1994 |last1=Smith |first1=M F }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1109/MM.1984.291314 |title=Automatic Assembler Source Translation from the Z80 to the MC6809 |journal=IEEE Micro |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=3–9 |year=1984 |last1=Smith |first1=M |last2=Luff |first2=B }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1109/TGRS.1981.350345 |title=A Microprocessor-Controlled Digitizer for Conductivity-Temperature-Depth Probes |journal=IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing |issue=3 |pages=157–160 |year=1981 |last1=Smith |first1=M. F }} * "Using interrupts for real time clocks". ''Byte'' (November 1977) pp 50–53 (https://archive.org/details/byte-magazine-1977-11).
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox government agency | name = Ministry of Health | native_name = {{Lang|ms|Kementerian Kesihatan}} | type = Ministry | jurisdiction = [[Government of Brunei]] | headquarters = [[Bandar Seri Begawan]], [[Brunei]] | coordinates = {{Coord|4.920762|114.944952|region:BN_type:landmark|display=inline,title|format=dms}} | budget = {{increase}}$345 million [[Brunei dollar|BND]] (2018) | minister1_name = [[Md Isham bin Jaafar]] | minister1_pfo = [[Minister of Health]] | website = http://www.moh.gov.bn }} The '''Ministry of Health''' ('''MOH''' or '''MoH'''; {{Lang-ms|Kementerian Kesihatan}}) is a cabinet-level [[Ministries of Brunei|ministry]] in the [[Government of Brunei]] which oversees [[health system]] in the country. The ministry is headed by the Minister of Health and the incumbent is [[Md Isham bin Jaafar]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rtbnews.rtb.gov.bn/Lists/News/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=4873|title=News - Announce and Appointment|website=www.rtbnews.rtb.gov.bn|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/sultan-attends-swearing-ceremony-new-health-minister/|title=Sultan attends swearing in ceremony of new health minister – Borneo Bulletin Online|date=2017-12-05|work=Borneo Bulletin Online|access-date=2018-01-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Budget == In the fiscal year 2018-19, the budget for Ministry of Health is allocated 345 million [[Brunei dollar|Brunei dollars]] ($262M as of March 2018),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/moh-tables-b345-million-budget/|title=MoH tables B$345 million budget {{!}} Borneo Bulletin Online|website=borneobulletin.com.bn|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thescoop.co/2018/03/18/moh-proposes-345million-budget/|title=Health Ministry to focus spending on improving patient care, reducing NCDs - The Scoop|date=2018-03-18|work=The Scoop|access-date=2018-03-21|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://xe.com/currencyconverter/convert/?Amount=345000000&From=BND&To=USD|title=XE: Convert BND/USD. Brunei Darussalam Dollar to United States Dollar|website=xe.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-21}}</ref> an increase from [[Brunei dollar|B$]]324 million in the previous year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://borneobulletin.com.bn/323-8m-health/|title=$323.8M for health {{!}} Borneo Bulletin Online|website=borneobulletin.com.bn|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thescoop.co/2018/03/21/14th-legco-session-ends-budget-passed/|title=14th LegCo session ends with $5.3B budget passed - The Scoop|date=2018-03-21|work=The Scoop|access-date=2018-03-21|language=en-GB}}</ref>

{{Infobox software | name = Mirth Connect | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | developer = [http://www.mirthcorp.com Mirth Corporation] | released = {{Start date and age|2006|07|18}} | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | genre = Integration engine | license = [[Mozilla Public License]] 1.1 | website = {{URL|http://www.mirthcorp.com/products/mirth-connect}} }}
'''Mirth Connect''' also known as ''Nextgen Connect'' is a cross-platform [[Health_Level_7|HL7]] interface engine that enables bi-directional sending of HL7 messages between systems and applications over multiple transports available under the Mozilla Public License (MPL) 1.1 license. On September 9th, 2013 Mirth Corporation announced they were acquired by [[Quality Systems]].<ref name="ACQUIRED">{{cite web|url=http://www.mirthcorp.com/news/quality-systems-acquires-mirth-corporation|title=Quality Systems, Inc. Acquires Mirth Corporation|date=2013-09-09|accessdate=2013-09-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923122839/http://www.mirthcorp.com/news/quality-systems-acquires-mirth-corporation|archivedate=2013-09-23|df=}}</ref>. MirthConnect has since been rebranded as NextgenConnect <ref>https://www.nextgen.com/products-and-services/integration-engine</ref>.
==Background== Mirth Connect uses a channel-based architecture to connect [[Health_information_technology|HIT]] systems and allow messages to be filtered, transformed, and routed based on user-defined rules. Channels consist of connectors (both inbound and outbound), filters, and transformers. Multiple filters and a chain of transformers can be associated with a channel.
Endpoints are used to configure connections and their protocol details. Source connectors are used to designate the type of listener to use for incoming messages, such as TCP/IP or a web service. Destination connectors are used to designate the destination of outgoing messages, such as an application server, a JMS queue, or a database. All messages and transactions are optionally logged to an internal database. Mirth Connect can be also configured to auto-generate an HL7 acknowledgement response (ACK).
==Connector varieties== Mirth Connect supports sending and receiving healthcare messages over a variety of protocols:
* TCP/MLLP * Database ([[MySQL]], [[PostgreSQL]], Oracle, Microsoft SQL Server, ODBC) * File (local file system and network shares) * PDF and RTF documents * [[Java_Message_Service|JMS]] * FTP/SFTP * [[HTTP]] * [[SMTP]] * [[SOAP]] (over HTTP)
An open architecture allows for the easy addition of custom and legacy interfaces.
==Types of transforms== * Mapping transformer: map data from incoming message to variables * Script transformer: execute custom script on message (Ex. JavaScript, Python, Tcl) * HL7 message generator: construct HL7 messages from data source * XSLT transformer: run XSL Transformations on incoming HL7 v3 or XML encoded messages
==Adopters== The [[Certification Commission for Healthcare Information Technology|Certification Commission for Healthcare Information Technology (CCHIT)]], in a push to ensure interoperability standards between electronic health records, has adopted [[Laika (EHR testing framework)|Laika]], an open source standards software program. At the 2009 Annual HIMSS Conference, Mirth was selected as one of the testing tools for the coming interoperability tests.<ref name="45YRSLATER">{{cite web|url=http://www.fredtrotter.com/category/himss/|title=Archive for the ‘HIMSS’ Category |publisher=Fred Trotter blog|date=2009-04-08| accessdate = 2009-04-16}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.mirthcorp.com/ The Mirthcorp website] * [https://www.outcomehealthcare.com/sample-mirth-connect-project-hl7-2-x-transformation-2-3-to-2-4/ Mirth Connect Sample HL7 2.x Transform Project] * [https://svn.mirthcorp.com/connect/ Mirth Source Code]

revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |type=secular |holiday_name=National Day of Mourning |duration= 1 day |scheduling = 28th day of April |frequency=annual |observedby=Canada |image = |caption= |date=28th day of April |longtype= |week_ordinal= |weekday= |month=April |celebrations=flag at half-mast, [[Moment of silence]], lighting candles, donning ribbons and black armbands |relatedto=[[Labor Day]]; [[Workers' Memorial Day]] }} The '''National Day of Mourning''', or '''Workers’ Mourning Day''' is observed in [[Canada]] on 28 April. It commemorates workers who have been killed, injured or suffered illness due to workplace related hazards and occupational exposures.
Workers' Memorial Day was started when two labour activists, Colin Lambert and Dr. Ray Sentes, were driving in early April 1983 to a union meeting, and were stopped by a funeral procession for a firefighter that had been killed in the line of duty<ref>{{Citation|last=BC Labour Heritage Centre|title=Day of Mourning The Untold Story (2017)|date=2017-04-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hP0JvrXjmgo&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2018-05-09}}</ref>. They worried that other workers who died because of work did not receive similar honours, and recalled how members of the United Steelworkers in Elliott Lake held each year a "Workers' Remembrance Day" for uranium miners who had succumbed to exposures. Lambert and Sentes sought endorsements from union officials for the idea to hold a national day of mourning, and the Canadian Union of Public Employees (CUPE) passed a resolution to that effect at its annual convention in 1983, and the Canadian Labour Congress followed suit at its annual convention the following year. The AFL-CIO declared a day of mourning in 1989 and a "workers' Memorial Day" is observed in over 100 countries.
In December 1990, this day became a national observance in Canada with the passing of the Workers Mourning Day Act, so that on April 28, 1991, it was officially the National Day of Mourning for persons killed or injured in the workplace; making April 28, an official Workers’ Mourning Day.<ref name="Manchester">[[Greater Manchester Hazards Centre]] Fact Sheet 28 April 2006 (GMHC is part of the [[Hazards Campaign]] recognised and affiliated to the UK [[Trades Union Congress]]) Author Hilda Palmer, (no ISBN); available at {{cite web |url=http://www.gmhazards.org.uk/WMDLft06.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060518055811/http://www.gmhazards.org.uk/WMDLft06.pdf |archivedate=2006-05-18 |df= }} Also '''Safety Express' March/ April 2006 Page 5'' 'April 28th is...Workers' Memorial Day' (no ISBN); published by The [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents]] ([[ROSPA]]) UK [[registered charity]] No. 207823</ref><ref name="ohs">TUC Certificate in Occupational Health & Safety course notes 2004/5 Section C page 69 (no ISBN); more info available at {{cite web |url=http://www.tuc.org.uk/h_and_s/index.cfm?mins=293 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100217003146/http://www.tuc.org.uk/h_and_s/index.cfm?mins=293 |archivedate=2010-02-17 |df= }}</ref>
Injuries and deaths in the workplace continue to be a matter of important concern across Canada. Many Canadians members work hard each day in an effort to minimize accidents and incidents. Risk is an inherent element of many jobs, and this is why safety should be one of the core values in any workplace. Since its inception, the observance has spread to over 80 countries around the world, but is known is most other countries as the [[Workers' Memorial Day]]. The date 28 April was picked because on that day in 1914, the [http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/workers-compensation/ Workers Compensation Act] received its third reading. In 2001 the [[International Labour Organization]] first observed World Day for Safety and Health at Work on this day. Commemorating those who have been hurt or killed in the workplace shows respect for the fallen, while serving as a reminder of the importance of occupational health and safety.
The Canadian flag is flown at half-mast from sunrise to sunset on all federal government buildings, including on Parliament Hill. Workers and employees observe this day in various ways including lighting candles, donning ribbons and black armbands, and observing a moment of silence at 1100 hrs. The purpose of Day of Mourning is twofold- to remember and honour those lives lost or injured and to renew the commitment to improving health and safety in the workplace - to prevent further deaths, injuries and diseases from work.
==Young Workers== Young workers aged from 15-24 are more likely than any other group to be injured on the job, in fact 1/3 of all injuries occur in this age group, and males are twice as likely to be injured as female workers.<ref name="YoungStats">[[WorkSafeBC]] Young Workers Rights and Facts, http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/6-FactSheet-Bugged-Revision-3-.pdf.</ref> The highest rate of injury happens in construction and hospitality industries. These rates have led to specific laws in many provinces that provide for additional and special training for young and new workers.<ref name="Young">[[WorkSafeBC]] Young Workers Resource and Fact Page, http://www2.worksafebc.com/Topics/YoungWorker/Home.asp.</ref> Due to these statistics, there has been renewed push to use this holiday to educate young workers of their rights in schools.<ref name="Schools">Day of Mourning, BC Schools Project, http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/domschoolsproject/</ref>
==Canadian monuments== Major monuments in Canada have been erected and dedicated to workers whose lives have been who have been killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{ccohs|date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/ |title=Monuments Canada }}.</ref>
* The Canadian Young Workers Memorial Quilt -The LifeQuilt with individual, personalized quilted blocks commemorated 100 young workers is a memorial dedicated to the thousands of young women and men between the ages of 14 and 24 killed on the job.<ref>{{date=2015 04 27|url=http://lifequilt.ca/ |title=Young Workers Memorial Life Quilt }}.</ref> * [[Canadian Labour Congress]] Monument, [[Vincent Massey Park]], [[Ottawa|Ottawa, Ontario]], Canada - This monument was dedicated on April 28, 1987, one year after the Canadian Labour Congress had officially established April 28 as the Day of Mourning to workers killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/labourcongress.html|title="Dead But Not Forgotten–Monuments to Workers" a book by Ed Thomas }}.</ref> * Falconbridge Mural, [[Sudbury, Ontario]], Canada * Miner's Memorial [[Kirkland Lake, Ontario]] Canada * [[Rideau Canal]] Fabric Mural Memorial, [[Kingston, Ontario]], Canada * Fire Fighter's Monument, [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]], Canada * "Breaking Ground" Hoggs Hollow Memorial, [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada * 'Their Light Shall Always Shine' Memorial Park, New Glasgow, Nova Scotia is a park and memorial dedicated to the 26 miners who lost their lives in a horrific mining explosion on May 9, 1992. http://ns1763.ca/pictouco/westraymem.html * "Broken Families Obelisk" Grant Notley Park, [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada * Welland Canal Fallen Workers Memorial, [[St. Catharines]], [[Ontario]], Canada
The [http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/ BC Labour Heritage Centre] maintains an [http://www.labourheritagecentre.ca/workermemorialmap/ interactive map] recording all monuments and plaques dedicated to working class people in British Columbia, over fifty sites of which are Day of Mourning specific.
==International monuments== Monuments around the world have been erected and dedicated to workers whose lives have been who have been killed and injured on the job.<ref>{{ccohs|date=2015 04 27|url=http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/ |title=Monuments International }}.</ref> * [[Hoover Dam]] Monument, [[Boulder City, Nevada]], USA * Airplane and Fishermen Monument, [[Hedinsfjordur, Iceland]] * Workers Memorial Day Stained Glass Window, [[Birmingham, England]] * Deceased Workers Memorial Forest [Adelaide South Australia} *National Deceased Workers Memorial (Workers Glade) [Canberra Australia]
==See also== *[[Labor Day]] *[[Workers' Memorial Day]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.hrsdc.gc.ca/eng/labour/health_safety/day_mourning.shtml National Day of Mourning at the Government of Canada] *[http://www.ccohs.ca/events/mourning/ National Day of Mourning at Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and Safety (CCOHS)] *[http://www.iapa.ca/main/about_iapa/2006_apr19_press.aspx Press release from the Industrial Accident Prevention Associate] *[http://www.ilo.org/public/english/protection/safework/worldday/ World Day for Safety and Health at Work- ILO] *[http://www.ciws.ca Canadian Injured Workers Society]
{{Occupational safety and health}}

revision.text:
[[File:Negative Air Pressure.png|thumb|300px|The internal air is forced out so that a negative air pressure is created pulling air passively into the system from other inlets.]] [[File:Beth-El Industries Isolation chamber inside view.jpg|thumb|Inside view of a negative pressure isolation chamber for patients with contagious diseases.]] '''Negative room pressure''' is an [[Isolation (health care)|isolation]] technique used in [[hospital]]s and medical centers to prevent cross-contaminations from room to room.<ref name="camil">[http://www.filterair.info/articles/article.cfm/ArticleID/BC9AA829-30F8-4406-8FEE4A1E17574D6B/Page/1 Negative Room Pressure to Prevent Cross-Contamination], Clean Air Solutions, Camil Farr, Retrieved 2010-03-10.</ref><ref>[http://www.engr.psu.edu/AE/iec/abe/control/isolation.asp Isolation Rooms & Pressurization Control], Penn State Department of Architectural Engineering, © 2008 The Pennsylvania State University. Retrieved 2010-03-10.</ref> It includes a [[ventilation (physiology)|ventilation]] system that generates negative pressure to allow air to flow into the isolation room but not escape from the room, as air will naturally flow from areas with higher pressure to areas with lower pressure, thereby preventing contaminated air from escaping the room. This technique is used to isolate patients with airborne [[contagious disease]]s such as [[tuberculosis]], measles, or [[chickenpox]].<ref>[http://www.airmontinc.com/negative-pressure.php Negative Pressure Isolation Rooms & Tuberculosis (TB) Isolation Rooms], AirMont Inc. Retrieved 2010-03-10.</ref><ref>P. N. Hoffman, a, M. J. Weinbrenb and S. A. Stuartc. [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WJP-4CMW025-1&_user=489286&_coverDate=08%2F31%2F2004&_rdoc=1&_fmt=high&_orig=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_searchStrId=1246564181&_rerunOrigin=google&_acct=C000022678&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=489286&md5=34f16ec347d8ee88cc6beffe12c207ae A practical lesson in negative-pressure isolation ventilation]. Journal of Hospital Infection. Volume 57, Issue 4, August 2004, Pages 345-346.</ref>
==Mechanism== [[File:Negative room.png|thumb|Schematic of a network of rooms where air (shown in blue) flows in one direction from the corridor into the negative pressure room (green). Exhaust air is safely removed from the area through a ventilation system.]] [[vacuum|Negative pressure]] is generated and maintained by a ventilation system that removes more exhaust air from the room than air is allowed into the room. Air is allowed into the room through a gap under the door (typically about one half-inch high). Except for this gap, the room should be as airtight as possible, allowing no air in through cracks and gaps, such as those around windows, light fixtures and electrical outlets. Leakage from these sources can compromise or eliminate room negative pressure.<ref name="camil"/>
==Smoke test== A [[smoke testing (mechanical)#Infectious disease control|smoke test]] can help determine whether a room is under negative pressure.<ref>[http://www.doc.state.mn.us/DocPolicy2/Document/500.522.htm Title: Negative Pressure Isolation Rooms], Minnesota Department of Corrections, Issue date 2007-07-03. Retrieved 2010-03-12.</ref> A tube containing smoke is held near the bottom of the negative pressure room door, about 2 inches in front of the door. The smoke tube is held parallel to the door, and a small amount of smoke is then generated by gently squeezing the bulb. Care is taken to release the smoke from the tube slowly to ensure the velocity of the smoke from the tube does not overpower the air velocity. If the room is at negative pressure, the smoke will travel under the door and into the room. If the room is not a negative pressure, the smoke will be blown outward or will stay stationary.
==See also== * [[Positive_pressure|Positive room pressure]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Health care]] [[Category:Infectious diseases]] [[Category:Pressure]] [[Category:Negative concepts]]

'''Polizeiwissenschaft''' ([[German language|German]] for "Police science", though "Polizei" may in this case be better translated as "Public Policy" or "Politics" in a broad sense) was a discipline born in the first third of the 18th century which lasted until the middle of the 19th century.
Considered as the science of the internal order of the community, it was a comprehensive term, which included today's [[public law]], [[Administration (business)|administrative]] science, the early [[political economy]], [[public health]] concerns, [[urbanism]] and [[urban planning]] (important in the light of the [[miasma theory of disease]]), etc. It overlapped with the simultaneously used term of ''Verwaltungswissenschaft'' (or "administrative science") and was a university course included in official trainings.
The first instruction chairs for "Cameralia Oeconomica and Polizeiwissenschaft" were created in 1727 by [[Frederick William I of Prussia]] in [[Halle, Saxony-Anhalt]] and [[Frankfurt (Oder)|Frankfurt]].One of the ''Polizeiwissenschaft'' first practitioners was [[Johann Friedrich von Pfeiffer]] born in Berlin and was a leading exponent of the theory on economic sustainability. ''Polizeiwissenschaft'' was quite distinct from today's use of the term "[[police]]", which is strictly reserved for law enforcement activities. It included "''Marktpolizei''" ("market police"), concerned with the surveillance of [[prices]] and economical activity, "''Gewerbeaufsicht''" ("surveillance of trade"), "''Bauaufsicht''" ("construction supervision") and "''Ausländerpolizei''" ("Foreigners' police").
The term has recently been used in a sense more closely related to contemporary police activities, used both as a comprehensive term as a synonym of "[[police science]]s" (including [[jurisprudence]], [[criminology]], [[sociology]], [[psychology]], [[political science]], [[forensics]], etc.).
== Bibliography == *[[Michel Foucault]], ''Security, Territory, population'' (1977-78 course, published 2004) *Wolfgang Wüst, ''Die „gute“ Policey im Reichskreis. Zur frühmodernen Normensetzung in den Kernregionen des Alten Reiches'', ** Bd. 1: ''Der Schwäbische Reichskreis, unter besonderer Berücksichtigung Bayerisch-Schwabens'', Berlin 2001, ** Bd. 2: ''Der Fränkische Reichskreis'', Berlin 2003, ** Bd. 3: ''Der Bayerische Reichskreis und die Oberpfalz'', Berlin 2004.
[[Category:Law enforcement theory]] [[Category:Public health]] [[Category:Public economics]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} [[File:Inequality and mortality in metro US.jpg|thumb|360px|Income inequality and [[death|mortality]] in 282 metropolitan areas of the [[United States]]. Mortality is [[Correlation|correlated]] with both income and inequality.]]
'''Population health''' has been defined as "the health outcomes of a group of individuals, including the distribution of such outcomes within the group".<ref name="pmid12604476">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kindig D, Stoddart G | date = March 2003 | title = What is population health? | url = http://www.ajph.org/cgi/reprint/93/3/380.pdf | format = PDF | journal = American Journal of Public Health | volume = 93 | issue = 3| pages = 380–3 | doi=10.2105/ajph.93.3.380 |pmid=12604476 | pmc=1447747}}</ref> It is an approach to [[health]] that aims to improve the [[health]] of an entire human population. This concept does not refer to animal or plant populations. It has been described as consisting of three components. These are "health outcomes, patterns of health determinants, and [[Population health policies and interventions|policies and interventions]]".<ref name="pmid12604476" /> A priority considered important in achieving the aim of Population Health is to reduce health inequities or disparities among different population groups due to, among other factors, the [[social determinants of health]], SDOH. The SDOH include all the factors (social, environmental, cultural and physical) that the different populations are born into, grow up and function with throughout their lifetimes which potentially have a measurable impact on the health of human populations.<ref>[http://www.healthypeople.gov/2020/topicsobjectives2020/overview.aspx?topicid=39 Social Determinants of Health overview tab.]</ref> The Population Health concept represents a change in the focus from the individual-level, characteristic of most mainstream [[medicine]]. It also seeks to complement the classic efforts of [[public health]] agencies by addressing a broader range of factors shown to impact the health of different populations. The World Health Organization's Commission on Social Determinants of Health, reported in 2008, that the SDOH factors were responsible for the bulk of diseases and injuries and these were the major causes of health inequities in all countries.<ref>[http://www.who.int/sdhconference/resources/Conference_Report.pdf Meeting Report of World Conference of Social Determinants of Health] held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 2008.</ref> In the US, SDOH were estimated to account for 70% of avoidable mortality.<ref>McGinnis JM, Williams-Russo P, Knickman JR. 2002. [http://content.healthaffairs.org/content/21/2/78.long "The case for more active policy attention to health promotion"]. ''Health Affairs'' '''21''' (2) pp.78–93. {{pmid|11900188}}. See also [http://www.nap.edu/catalog/10548.html National Academies Press free publication: The Future of Public Health in the 21st Century.]</ref>
From a population health perspective, health has been defined not simply as a state free from disease but as "the capacity of people to adapt to, respond to, or control life's challenges and changes".<ref>Frankish, CJ et al. [http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/ph-sp/impact-repercussions/hiatp2.php "Health Impact Assessment as a Tool for Population Health Promotion and Public Policy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308083354/http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/ph-sp/impact-repercussions/hiatp2.php |date=8 March 2010 }}. Vancouver: Institute of Health Promotion Research, University of British Columbia, 1996. Retrieved 12 October 2008.</ref> The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) defined health in its broader sense in 1946 as "a state of complete physical, mental, and social [[well-being]] and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity."<ref name="WHO definition">World Health Organization. [http://www.who.int/bulletin/archives/80(12)981.pdf ''WHO definition of Health''], Preamble to the Constitution of the World Health Organization as adopted by the International Health Conference, New York, 19–22 June 1946; signed on 22 July 1946 by the representatives of 61 States (Official Records of the World Health Organization, no. 2, p. 100) and entered into force on 7 April 1948. In {{cite journal|journal=Bulletin of the World Health Organization |year=2002|volume= 80 |issue=12|page=982|title=The Preamble of the Constitution of the World Health Organization|author=Grad, Frank P. }}</ref><ref name="WHO constitution">World Health Organization. 2006. [http://www.who.int/governance/eb/who_constitution_en.pdf ''Constitution of the World Health Organization''] – ''Basic Documents'', Forty-fifth edition, Supplement, October 2006.</ref>
==Healthy People 2020==
Healthy People 2020 is a web site sponsored by the [[US Department of Health and Human Services]], representing the cumulative effort of 34 years of interest by the Surgeon General's office and others. It identifies 42 topics considered [[social determinants of health]] and approximately 1200 specific goals considered to improve population health. It provides links to the current research available for selected topics and identifies and supports the need for community involvement considered essential to address these problems realistically.<ref>[http://www.healthypeople.gov/2020/default.aspx Health People 2020]</ref>
==The human role of economic inequality==
Recently, human role has been encouraged by the influence of population growth there has been increasing interest from [[epidemiology|epidemiologists]] on the subject of [[economic inequality]] and its relation to the health of populations. There is a very robust correlation between [[Social status|socioeconomic status]] and health. This correlation suggests that it is not only the poor who tend to be sick when everyone else is healthy, [[heart disease]], [[Peptic ulcer|ulcers]], [[type 2 diabetes]], [[rheumatoid arthritis]], certain types of [[cancer]], and [[premature aging]]. Despite the reality of the [[Socioeconomic status#health|SES Gradient]], there is debate as to its cause. A number of researchers (A. Leigh, C. Jencks, A. Clarkwest—see also Russell Sage working papers) see a definite link between economic status and mortality due to the greater economic resources of the better-off, but they find little correlation due to [[social status]] differences.
Other researchers such as [[Richard G. Wilkinson]], J. Lynch, and G.A. Kaplan have found that socioeconomic status strongly affects health even when controlling for economic resources and access to health care. Most famous for linking social status with health are the [[Whitehall Study|Whitehall studies]]—a series of studies conducted on [[civil servants]] in [[London]]. The studies found that, despite the fact that all civil servants in England have the same access to health care, there was a strong correlation between social status and health. The studies found that this relationship stayed strong even when controlling for health-affecting habits such as [[exercise]], [[Tobacco smoking|smoking]] and [[Alcoholic beverage|drinking]]. Furthermore, it has been noted that no amount of medical attention will help decrease the likelihood of someone getting [[type 1 diabetes]] or [[rheumatoid arthritis]]—yet both are more common among populations with lower socioeconomic status. Lastly, it has been found that amongst the wealthiest quarter of countries on earth (a set stretching from [[Luxembourg]] to [[Slovakia]]) there is no relation between a country's wealth and general population health{{ref|sci_amer_dec_2005}}—suggesting that past a certain level, absolute levels of wealth have little impact on population health, but relative levels within a country do. The concept of [[psychosocial stress]] attempts to explain how psychosocial phenomenon such as [[Social status|status]] and [[social stratification]] can lead to the many diseases associated with the [[SES gradient]]. Higher levels of economic inequality tend to intensify social hierarchies and generally degrades the quality of social relations—leading to greater levels of [[Stress (medicine)|stress]] and stress related diseases. Richard Wilkinson found this to be true not only for the poorest members of society, but also for the wealthiest. Economic inequality is bad for everyone's health.''' Inequality does not only affect the health of human populations. David H. Abbott at the Wisconsin National Primate Research Center found that among many primate species, less egalitarian social structures correlated with higher levels of stress hormones among socially subordinate individuals. Research by [[Robert Sapolsky]] of [[Stanford University]] provides similar findings.
==Research== There is well-documented variation in health outcomes and health care utilization & costs by geographic variation in the U.S., down to the level of Hospital Referral Regions (defined as a regional health care market, which may cross state boundaries, of which there are 306 in the U.S.).<ref>{{cite book |author1=Chandra, A |author2=Skinner, JS | title= Geography and Racial Health Disparities, Chapter 16 of Critical Perspectives on Racial and Ethnic Differences in Health in Late Life. |year=2004|publisher=National Research Council|url=https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/6555551.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.dartmouthatlas.org/data/region/| title=Data by Region, the Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care|accessdate=16 November 2013}}</ref> There is ongoing debate as to the relative contributions of race, gender, poverty, education level and place to these variations. The Office of Epidemiology of the [[Maternal and Child Health Bureau]] recommends using an analytic approach (Fixed Effects or hybrid Fixed Effects) to research on health disparities to reduce the confounding effects of neighborhood (geographic) variables on the outcomes.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Schempf, AH, Kaufman, JS | title= Accounting for context in studies of health inequalities: a review and comparison of analytic approaches. | journal=Annals of Epidemiology |volume=10| issue= 10 | year=2012|doi=10.1016/j.annepidem.2012.06.105 | pmid= 22858050 | pages=683–690| url= https://zenodo.org/record/1258734 | type= Submitted manuscript }}</ref>
==The importance of family planning programs== [[Family planning]] programs (including [[Birth control|contraceptives]], [[sex education|sexuality education]], and promotion of [[safe sex]]) play a major role in population health. Family planning is one of the most highly cost-effective interventions in medicine.<ref name=Tsui>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tsui AO, McDonald-Mosley R, Burke AE |title=Family planning and the burden of unintended pregnancies |journal=Epidemiol Rev |volume=32 |issue=1 |pages=152–74 |date=April 2010 |pmid=20570955 |pmc=3115338 |doi=10.1093/epirev/mxq012 |url= | quote=International studies confirm that family planning is among the most cost-effective of all health interventions (80, 81). The cost savings stem from a reduction in unintended pregnancy, as well as a reduction in transmission of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV.}}</ref><!-- page 170 --> Family planning saves lives and money by reducing [[unintended pregnancy]] and the transmission of [[sexually transmitted infection]]s.<ref name=Tsui />
For example, the [[United States Agency for International Development]] lists as benefits of its international family planning program:<ref>USAID. [http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/pop/ Family planning] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015184505/http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/global_health/pop/ |date=15 October 2008 }}. Retrieved 12 October 2008.</ref>
* "Protecting the health of women by reducing high-risk pregnancies" * "Protecting the health of children by allowing sufficient time between pregnancies" * "Fighting HIV/[[AIDS]] through providing information, counseling, and access to [[condom|male]] and [[female condom]]s" * "Reducing [[abortions]]" * "Supporting women's rights and opportunities for education, employment, and full participation in society" * "Protecting the environment by stabilizing population growth"
==Population health management (PHM)== One method to improve population health is population health management (PHM), which has been defined as "the technical field of endeavor which utilizes a variety of individual, organizational and cultural interventions to help improve the [[morbidity]] patterns (i.e., the illness and injury burden) and the health care use behavior of defined populations".<ref>Hillman, Michael. [http://waysandmeans.house.gov/Legacy/health/107cong/4-16-02/4-16hill.htm Testimony before the Subcommittee on Health of the House Committee on Ways and Means, hearing on promoting disease management in Medicare]. 16 April 2002. Retrieved 12 October 2008.</ref> PHM is distinguished from [[Disease management (health)|disease management]] by including more [[Chronic (medical)|chronic]] conditions and diseases, by use of "a single point of contact and coordination", and by "[[predictive modeling]] across multiple clinical conditions".<ref>Howe, Rufus, and Christopher Spence. [http://www.healthways.com/assets/0/98/E4CDDEDB-5004-4E74-A5C9-E1973F5ABC05.pdf Population health management: Healthways' PopWorks] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217114011/http://www.healthways.com/assets/0/98/E4CDDEDB-5004-4E74-A5C9-E1973F5ABC05.pdf |date=17 December 2008 }}. ''HCT Project'' 2004-07-17, volume 2, chapter 5, pages 291-297. Retrieved 12 October 2008.</ref> PHM is considered broader than disease management in that it also includes "intensive care management for individuals at the highest level of risk" and "personal health management... for those at lower levels of predicted health risk".<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Coughlin JF, Pope J, Leedle BR | date = Apr 2006 | title = Old age, new technology, and future innovations in disease management and home health care | url = http://web.mit.edu/agelab/news_events/pdfs/home.health.care.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Home Health Care Management & Practice | volume = 18 | issue = 3| pages = 196–207 | doi=10.1177/1084822305281955}}</ref> Many PHM-related articles are published in ''Population Health Management'', the official journal of [[DMAA: The Care Continuum Alliance]].<ref>DMAA: The Care Continuum Alliance. [http://www.dmaa.org/pubs_dm_journal.asp Publications. ''Population Health Management''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924053436/http://www.dmaa.org/pubs_dm_journal.asp |date=24 September 2008 }}. Retrieved 12 October 2008.</ref>
The following road map has been suggested for helping healthcare organizations navigate the path toward implementing effective population health management:<ref>Sanders, Dale [http://www.healthcatalyst.com/landmark-review-of-population-health-management-companies A Landmark, 12-Point Review of Population Health Management Companies]. Retrieved 17 March 2014.</ref> *Establish precise [[Disease registry|patient registries]] *Determine patient-provider attribution *Define precise numerators in the patient registries *Monitor and measure clinical and cost metrics *Adhere to basic [[Medical guideline|clinical practice guidelines]] *Engage in risk-management outreach *Acquire external data *Communicate with patients *[[Patient education|Educate patients]] and engage with them *Establish and adhere to complex clinical practice guidelines *Coordinate effectively between care team and patient *Track specific outcomes
== Healthcare reform and population health == Healthcare reform is driving change to traditional hospital reimbursement models. Prior to the introduction of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA)]], hospitals were reimbursed based on the volume of procedures through [[fee-for-service]] models. Under the PPACA, reimbursement models are shifting from volume to value. New reimbursement models are built around [[Pay for performance (healthcare)|pay for performance]], a value-based reimbursement approach, which places financial incentives around patient outcomes and has drastically changed the way US hospitals must conduct business to remain financially viable.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Revised Medicare ACO Program: More Options … And More Work Ahead|url = http://healthaffairs.org/blog/2015/06/16/the-revised-medicare-aco-program-more-options-and-more-work-ahead/|website = Health Affairs|accessdate = 21 November 2015}}</ref> In addition to focusing on improving patient experience of care and reducing costs, hospitals must also focus on improving the health of populations (IHI Triple Aim<ref>{{Cite web|title = The IHI Triple Aim|url = http://www.ihi.org/engage/initiatives/TripleAim/Pages/default.aspx|website = www.ihi.org|accessdate = 21 November 2015}}</ref>).
As participation in value-based reimbursement models such as [[accountable care organization]]s (ACOs) increases, these initiatives will help drive population health.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=DeVore S, Champion RW |title=Driving Population Health Through Accountable Care Organizations|journal=Health Affairs |year=2011|volume=30|issue=1|pages=41–50|doi=10.1377/hlthaff.2010.0935|pmid=21209436|url=http://content.healthaffairs.org/content/30/1/41.long}}</ref> Within the ACO model, hospitals have to meet specific quality benchmarks, focus on prevention, and carefully manage patients with chronic diseases.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Accountable Care Organizations, Explained|url = http://khn.org/news/aco-accountable-care-organization-faq/|website = Kaiser Health News|accessdate = 21 November 2015|language = en-US|date = 2015-09-14}}</ref> Providers get paid more for keeping their patients healthy and out of the hospital.<ref name=":0" /> Studies have shown that inpatient admission rates have dropped over the past ten years in communities that were early adopters of the ACO model and implemented population health measures to treat "less sick" patients in the outpatient setting.<ref>Kutscher B. [http://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20120804/MAGAZINE/308049929 Outpatient care takes the inside track]. Modern Healthcare. 2012. Retrieved 31 October 2015.</ref> A study conducted in the Chicago area showed a decline in inpatient utilization rates across all age groups, which was an average of a 5% overall drop in inpatient admissions.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Where Have All The Inpatients Gone? A Regional Study With National Implications|url = http://healthaffairs.org/blog/2014/01/06/where-have-all-the-inpatients-gone-a-regional-study-with-national-implications/|website = Health Affairs|accessdate = 21 November 2015}}</ref>
Hospitals are finding it financially advantageous to focus on population health management and keeping people in the community well.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Population Health Management: Hospitals' Changing Employer Role|url = http://www.beckershospitalreview.com/workforce-labor-management/population-health-management-hospitals-changing-employer-role.html|website = www.beckershospitalreview.com|accessdate = 21 November 2015}}</ref> The goal of population health management is to improve patient outcomes and increase health capital. Other goals include preventing disease, closing care gaps, and cost savings for providers.<ref>{{Cite web|title = What is Population Health Management?|url = http://www.wellcentive.com/what-is-population-health-management/|website = Wellcentive|accessdate = 21 November 2015|language = en-US}}</ref> In the last few years, more effort has been directed towards developing telehealth services, community-based clinics in areas with high proportion of residents using the emergency department as primary care, and patient care coordinator roles to coordinate healthcare services across the care continuum.<ref name=":1" />
Health can be considered a capital good; health capital is part of human capital as defined by the Grossman model.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Grossman M | year = 1972 | title = On the Concept of Health Capital and the Demand for Health | url = | journal = Journal of Political Economy | volume = 80 | issue = 2| pages = 223–255 | doi=10.1086/259880| citeseerx = 10.1.1.604.7202}}</ref> Health can be considered both an investment good and consumption good.<ref name=":2">Folland S, Goodman A, Stano M. The economics of health and health care (Vol. 6): Upper Saddle River: Pearson Education; 2007.</ref> Factors such as obesity and smoking have negative effects on health capital, while education, wage rate, and age may also impact health capital.<ref name=":2" /> When people are healthier through preventative care, they have the potential to live a longer and healthier life, work more and participate in the economy, and produce more based on the work done. These factors all have the potential to increase earnings. Some states, like New York, have implemented statewide initiatives to address population health. In New York state there are 11 such programs. One example is the Mohawk Valley Population Health Improvement Program (http://www.mvphip.org/). These programs work to address the needs of the people in their region, as well as assist their local community based organizations and social services to gather data, address health disparities, and explore evidence-based interventions that will ultimately lead to better health for everyone. Following a similar approach, Cullati et al. developed a theoretical framework for the development and onset of vulnerability in later life based on the concept of "reserves".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cullati|first=Stéphane|last2=Kliegel|first2=Matthias|last3=Widmer|first3=Eric|date=2018|title=Development of reserves over the life course and onset of vulnerability in later life|journal=Nature Human Behaviour|language=En|volume=2|issue=8|pages=551–558|doi=10.1038/s41562-018-0395-3|issn=2397-3374}}</ref> The advantages to use the concept of reserves in interdisciplinary studies, as compared with related concepts such as resources and capital, is to strengthen the importance of constitution and sustainability of reserves (the “use it or lose it” paradigm) and the presence of thresholds, below which functioning becomes challenging.
==See also== * [[Auxology]] * [[Community health]] * [[Economic inequality]] * [[Health disparities]] * [[Health impact assessment]] * [[Inequality in disease]] * [[List of countries by income equality]] * [[Population Health Forum]] * [[Social determinants of health]] * [[popHealth]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
== Further reading ==
* {{cite journal |title = Global and regional burden of disease and risk factors, 2001: systematic analysis of population health data |journal = [[The Lancet]] |volume = 367 |issue = 9524 |pages = 1747–1757 |date = 27 May 2006 |url = http://www.fic.nih.gov/news/fogarty/2006/dcpp_lancet_367.pdf |doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(06)68770-9 |pmid = 16731270 |vauthors = Lopez AD, Mathers CD, Ezzati M, Jamison DT, Murray CJ |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090323190128/http://www.fic.nih.gov/news/fogarty/2006/dcpp_lancet_367.pdf |archivedate = 23 March 2009 |df = dmy-all }}
==External links== * [http://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/iphi/ Institute for Population Health Improvement] at the University of California-Davis Health System * [http://pophealth.med.nyu.edu/ New York University Department of Population Health] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081010172719/http://www.pophealth.wisc.edu/uwphi Population Health Institute] at the University of Wisconsin–Madison * [http://www.cihi.ca Canadian Institute for Health Information] * [http://www.curemd.com/ice.asp PHM ICE] Government supported ACO * [http://www.iph.uottawa.ca/ Institute of Population Health] at the University of Ottawa, Canada * [https://archive.is/20070312002845/http://www.jhsph.edu/dept/pfrh/PFHS_Preview/Population_and_Health.html Population and Health Graduate Program] in the Dept. of Population and Family Health Sciences at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health * [[Population Health Forum]] [http://depts.washington.edu/eqhlth website] * [http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/ph-sp/phdd/ Public Health Agency of Canada's take on population health] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060211120720/http://policyresearch.gc.ca/doclib/horizonsv2n3e.pdf Canadian Policy Research Secretariate report on population health] * [http://www.psp-one.com Private Sector Partnerships for Better Health]

revision.text:
{{advert|date=October 2018}} {{primary|date=October 2018}} {{coi|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox organization | name = | image = Seva Foundation 2018 Logo.jpg | size = 200px | alt = | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | abbreviation = | motto = Compassion in Action | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date|1978}} | extinction = | type = [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]] | status = | purpose = Prevention of blindness. | headquarters = 1786 Fifth Street | location = Berkeley, California, United States | coords = | region_served = Worldwide | membership = | language = | general = | leader_title = Executive Director | leader_name = Kate Moynihan<ref name=Staff>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seva.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about/our_staff|title=Staff|publisher=Seva Foundation|accessdate=July 31, 2018}}</ref> | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = {{URL|http://www.seva.org/}} | remarks = | former name = }} '''Seva Foundation''' is an international non-profit health organization based in [[Berkeley, California]] known for preventing and treating blindness and other [[visual impairment]]s. It was co-founded in 1978 by Dr. [[Larry Brilliant]], [[Ram Dass]], [[Wavy Gravy]], [[Nicole Grasset]] and [[Govindappa Venkataswamy]]. [[Steve Jobs]] served as an early adviser and major contributor.
Seva works with local communities in more than 20 countries around the world to develop locally-run, culturally appropriate, self-sustaining programs to increase access to eye care. Seva works with local eye health hospitals and clinics in central Asia, southeast Asia, Eastern Europe, Latin America, and throughout sub-Saharan Africa. The foundation also works with Native communities in North America through its [[Seva Foundation#American Indian Sight Initiative|American Indian Sight Initiative]].
==History== Seva Foundation, based in [[Berkeley, California]], was founded in 1978 by public health expert [[Larry Brilliant]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/30/business/30charity.html|title= Google Finds It Hard to Reinvent Philanthropy|date=January 29, 2011|accessdate=January 4, 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|first=Stephanie|last=Strom}}</ref> spiritual leader [[Ram Dass]] and humanitarian activist [[Wavy Gravy]].<ref name="About">{{cite web|url=http://www.seva.org/about_seva |title=About Seva Foundation|publisher=Seva Foundation|accessdate=December 11, 2012}}</ref> Other co-founders include Dr. [[Govindappa Venkataswamy]], founder of the [[Aravind Eye Hospital|Aravind Eye Foundation]], and [[Nicole Grasset]], the senior adviser for the [[World Health Organization]] [[smallpox]] [[Smallpox vaccine|eradication]] campaign.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seva.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about_history|title=Celebrating 35 Years of Service: Seva Foundation's history of Compassion in Action|accessdate=December 14, 2013|publisher=Seva Foundation|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106192001/http://www.seva.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about_history|archivedate=January 6, 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/handle/10665/68228|title=Programme d' éradication de la variole dans la République de Djibouti : évaluation de la situation actuelle et exécution des activités de surveillance : 6 novembre-30 décembre 1977 / par Nicole Grasset|accessdate=December 14, 2013|publisher=[[World Health Organization]]|language=French}}</ref> [[Steve Jobs]] also participated as an adviser at early Seva meetings and provided the first significant cash donation along with an [[Apple II]] to enter and analyze [[Optometry|eye care]] survey results in the original Nepal program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/11/20/a-gift-from-steve-jobs-returns-home/?_r=0|title=A Gift From Steve Jobs Returns Home|first=Nick|last=Wingfield|accessdate=January 4, 2013|date=November 20, 2013|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Himalayan Cataract Project]], a similar charity

{{Infobox disease | Name = Smokeless tobacco keratosis | Image = | Caption = | Field = [[Oral medicine]] | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | eMedicine_mult = | MeshID = }}
'''Smokeless tobacco keratosis''' (abbreviated to STK,<ref name=Greer2011>{{cite journal|last1=Greer RO|first1=Jr|title=Oral manifestations of smokeless tobacco use.|journal=Otolaryngologic clinics of North America|date=February 2011|volume=44|issue=1|pages=31–56, v|pmid=21093622|doi=10.1016/j.otc.2010.09.002}}</ref> also termed '''snuff dippers' keratosis''',<ref name=Scully2013>{{cite book|author=Scully C|title=Oral and Maxillofacial Medicine: The Basis of Diagnosis and Treatment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U3WyAFrXVfIC&pg=PA388|year=2013|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=0-7020-4948-4|pages=287–288|edition=3rd}}</ref> '''smokeless tobacco-associated keratosis''',<ref name=Ibsen2014>{{cite book|author1=Ibsen OAC|author2=Phelan JA|title=Oral Pathology for the Dental Hygienist|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nsvsAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA54|date=14 April 2014|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-0-323-29130-9|page=54}}</ref> '''snuff pouch''',<ref name=Neville2008>{{cite book|vauthors = Chi AC, Damm DD, Neville BW, Allen CA, Bouquot J|title=Oral and Maxillofacial Pathology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5QIEAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA399|date=11 June 2008|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-1-4377-2197-3|pages=398–401}}</ref> '''snuff dipper's lesion''',<ref name=Neville2008 /> '''tobacco pouch keratosis''',<ref name=Neville2008 /> or '''spit tobacco keratosis''')<ref name=Neville2008 /> is a condition which develops on the [[oral mucosa]] (the lining of the mouth) in response to [[smokeless tobacco]] use. Generally it appears as a white patch, located at the point where the tobacco is held in the mouth. The condition usually disappears once the tobacco habit is stopped. It is associated with slightly increased risk of [[mouth cancer]].
==Background== There are many types of smokeless tobacco. [[Chewing tobacco]] is shredded, air-cured tobacco with flavoring. [[Dipping tobacco]] ("moist snuff") is air or fire-cured, finely cut tobacco. [[Dry snuff]] is ground or pulverised tobacco leaves. In the Indian subcontinent, the Middle-East and South-East Asia, tobacco may be combined in a [[Chewing tobacco|quid]] or [[paan]] with other ingredients such as [[betel]] leaf, [[Areca nut]] and [[slaked lime]].<ref name=Neville2008 /><ref name=Eversole2011>{{cite book|author=Eversole LR|title=Clinical Outline of Oral Pathology: Diagnosis and Treatment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N0ng2f1hxn4C&pg=PA16|year=2011|publisher=PMPH-USA|isbn=978-1-60795-015-8|pages=14–16}}</ref> Use of Areca nut is associated with [[oral submucous fibrosis]].<ref name=Neville2008 /> An appearance termed '''Betel chewer's mucosa''' describes [[morsicatio buccarum]] with red-staining of mucosa due to betel quid ingredients.<ref name=Neville2008 /> In Scandinavian countries, [[snus]], a variant of dry snuff, is sometimes used.<ref name=Werning2011 /> In the United States of America, the most common form of smokeless tobacco is dipping tobacco, although chewing tobacco is sometimes used by outdoor workers and dry snuff is common among females in the Southern states.<ref name=Neville2008 /><ref name=Werning2011 /> The overall prevalence of smokeless tobacco use in the USA is about 4.5%, but this is higher in Mid-Western and Southern states.<ref name=Neville2008 />
==Signs and symptoms== STK typically occurs in the buccal sulcus (inside the cheek) or the labial sulcus (between the lips and the teeth) and corresponds to the site where the tobacco is held in the mouth.<ref name=Werning2011>{{cite book|author=Werning JW|title=Oral Cancer: Diagnosis, Management, and Rehabilitation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JuJSf8kTsqUC&pg=PA13|date=1 January 2011|publisher=Thieme|isbn=978-1-60406-485-8|pages=12–13}}</ref> It is painless.<ref name=Laskaris2011 />
The appearance of the lesion is variable depending upon the type of tobacco used, and the frequency and duration of use.<ref name=Werning2011 /> It takes about 1-5 years of smokeless tobacco use for the lesion to appear.<ref name=Laskaris2011>{{cite book|author=Laskaris G|title=Treatment of Oral Diseases: A Concise Textbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GRmfM9dv0vYC&pg=PA167|date=1 January 2011|publisher=Thieme|isbn=978-3-13-161371-4|page=157}}</ref> Early lesions may appear as thin, translucent and granular or wrinkled mucosa.<ref name=Ibsen2014 /><ref name=Werning2011 /> The later lesion may appear thicker, more opaquely white and [[hyperkeratosis|hyperkeratotic]] with fissures and folds.<ref name=Werning2011 /><ref name=Ibsen2014 /> Oral snuff causes more pronounced changes in the oral mucosa than tobacco chewing.<ref name=Scully2013 /> Snuff dipping is associated more with verrucous keratosis.<ref name=Scully2013 />
As well as the white changes of the oral mucosa, there may be [[gingival recession]] (receding gums) and staining of tooth roots in the area where the tobacco is held.<ref name=Laskaris2011 />
==Diagnosis== {{See also|Leukoplakia#Differential diagnosis of an oral white patch}} Diagnosis is mainly clinical, based on the history and clinical appearance. The [[differential diagnosis]] includes other oral white lesions such as [[Leukoplakia]], [[squamous cell carcinoma]], [[oral candidiasis]], [[lichen planus]], [[white sponge nevus]] and [[contact stomatitis]].<ref name=Laskaris2011 /> In contrast to pseudomembraneous candidiasis, this white patch cannot be wiped off.<ref name=Laskaris2011 /> [[Tissue biopsy]] is sometimes carried out to rule out other lesions, although biopsy is not routinely carried out for this condition.<ref name=Petruzzelli2008 />
==Treatment== Apart from stopping the habit, no other treatment is indicated.<ref name=Scully2013 /> Long term follow-up is usually carried out.<ref name=Scully2013 /> Some recommend biopsy if the lesions persists more than 6 weeks after giving up smokeless tobacco use,<ref name=Laskaris2011 /> or if the lesion undergoes a change in appearance (e.g. [[mouth ulcer|ulceration]], thickening, color changes, especially to speckled white and red or entirely red).<ref name=Petruzzelli2008 /> [[Surgical excision]] may be carried out if the lesion does not resolve.<ref name=Laskaris2011 />
==Prognosis== Usually this lesion is reversible if the tobacco habit is stopped completely,<ref name=Werning2011 /> even after many years of use.<ref name=Scully2013 /> In one report, 98% of lesions disappeared within 2 weeks of stopping tobacco use.<ref name=Neville2008 /> The risk of the lesion developing into oral cancer (generally [[squamous cell carcinoma]]<ref name=Werning2011 /> and its variant [[verrucous carcinoma]])<ref name=Scully2013 /> is relatively low.<ref name=Greer2011 /> Indeed, veruccous carcinoma is sometimes term '''snuff dipper's cancer'''.<ref name=Neville2008 /> In most reported cases, malignant transformation has occurring in individuals with a very long history of chewing tobacco or who use dry snuff.<ref name=Werning2011 />
Smokeless tobacco use is also accompanied by increased risk of other oral conditions such as [[dental caries]] (tooth decay), [[periodontitis]] (gum disease), [[attrition (dental)|attrition]] (tooth wear) and staining.<ref name=Ibsen2014 />
==Epidemiology== STK is extremely common among smokeless tobacco users.<ref name=Petruzzelli2008>{{cite book|author=Petruzzelli GJ|title=Practical Head and Neck Oncology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JOEzBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA237|date=1 September 2008|publisher=Plural Publishing|isbn=978-1-59756-783-1|pages=237–238}}</ref> Given the association with smokeless tobacco use, this condition tends to occur in adults.<ref name=Scully2013 /> A national USA survey estimated an overall prevalence of 1.5% of all types of smokeless tobacco lesions, with males affected more commonly than females.<ref name=Neville2008 />
==See also== * [[Stomatitis nicotina]] * [[Smoker's melanosis]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Oral pathology}} {{Smoking nav}}
[[Category:Oral mucosal pathology]] [[Category:Health effects of tobacco]]

{{Primary sources|article|date=April 2007}}
{{About|SANBI: Bioinformatics Institute|SANBI: Biodiversity Instute|Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden}} The '''South African National Bioinformatics Institute (SANBI)''' is a [[non-profit organisation]] in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]] dedicated to [[bioinformatics]], [[biotechnology]] and [[genomics]] in [[health]] [[research]].
SANBI maintains current collaborations with institutes and laboratories at [[Harvard University]], [[Oxford University]], [[Cambridge University]], [[Stanford University]], the [[Pasteur Institute]], the [[RIKEN]] institute, the [[Allen Institute for Brain Science]], the [[Institut National de la Santé et de la Recherche Médicale]] and the [[European Bioinformatics Institute]].
SANBI is the South African national node of the [[European Molecular Biology Network]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.embnet.org/node/51 |title= SANBI National Node |work= EMBnet website |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070927133200/http://www.embnet.org/node/51 |archivedate= 2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref> the regional site for the [[World Health Organization]] African centre for training in [[pathogen]] bioinformatics,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.who.int/tdr/research/progress/0102/knowledge/en/index.html |title= TDR-supported regional training centres in bioinformatics |work= Tropical Disease Research website }}</ref> and an affiliate of the [[Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research]].
SANBI is funded by several organisations including the [[South African Medical Research Council]], the [[National Research Foundation of South Africa]], the Claude Leon Foundation, the [[John E. Fogarty]] Foundation for International Health at the [[National Institutes of Health]], and the [[European Commission]].
SANBI was founded<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sanbi.ac.za/about-us/ |title= SANBI History |work= SANBI website |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071017021310/http://www.sanbi.ac.za/about-us/ |archivedate= 2007-10-17 |df= }}</ref> in 1996 by [[Computational biology|computational biologist]] Winston Hide, the founding [[Director (education)|director]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sanbi.ac.za/people-2/external-faculty/winston-hide/ |title= Win Hide (Director) |work= Senior faculty page, SANBI website |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110504175318/http://www.sanbi.ac.za/people-2/external-faculty/winston-hide/ |archivedate= 2011-05-04 |df= }}</ref> as part of the [[Faculty (university)|faculty]] of [[Natural Sciences]] of the [[University of the Western Cape]]. The SANBI research team includes faculty in the areas of [[genetic diversity]], [[gene regulation]], [[cancer]], [[African trypanosomiasis|sleeping sickness]] and the [[Human Immunodeficiency Virus]].
==See also== * [[Computational biology]]
==References== <!--<references/>--> {{reflist}} {{University of the Western Cape}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060814045054/http://www.nbn.ac.za/ National Bioinformatics Network] of South Africa * [http://www.asbcb.org African Society for Bioinformatics and Computational Biology] * [http://www.leonfoundation.co.za/ The Claude Leon Foundation] * [http://tagc.univ-mrs.fr/welcome/ Technologies Avancées pour le Génome et la Clinique] (TAGC) * [http://www.ebi.ac.uk European Bioinformatics Institute] (EBI) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070413173851/http://www.fic.nih.gov/index.htm John E. Fogarty International Center (FIC)] for Advanced Study in the Health Sciences

revision.text:
Launched in October 2008, the '''Southern AIDS Living Quilt''' is a website dedicated to promoting awareness of the growing impact of [[HIV/AIDS]] on women in the southern United States, particularly women of color.<ref name=miami>Burch, Audra D.S. “The living quilt: South Florida women fight the stigma of HIV/AIDS.” The Miami Herald, Nov. 4, 2008 <http://www.miamiherald.com/living/v-fullstory/story/754540.html>.</ref>
The site is a project of the Southern AIDS Coalition, a non-profit membership organization of government representatives, corporations, and community advocates.<ref name=sac>Southern AIDS Coalition <http://www.southernaidscoalition.org/>.</ref> Using video testimonials, the Living Quilt compiles stories of women living with HIV/AIDS, as well as healthcare providers and patient advocates in the South.<ref name=observe>Avery, Sarah. “Web site designed for women with HIV/AIDS.” Oct. 29, 2008 <http://www.newsobserver.com/150/story/1272869.html>.</ref> More than 80 women are represented on the Living Quilt from 13 southern states including [[Alabama]], [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Kentucky]], [[Louisiana]], [[Maryland]], [[Mississippi]], [[North Carolina]], [[South Carolina]], [[Tennessee]], [[Texas]], [[Virginia]] and [[Washington, D.C.]]
Several notable Living Quilt participants include CNN Hero <ref name=hero>2008 CNN Heroes Archive <http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cnn.heroes/archive/bambi.gaddist.html></ref> Dr. Bambi W. Gaddist <ref name=bambi>Bambi Gaddist biography <http://www.livingquilt.org/bambi.html></ref> of the South Carolina HIV/AIDS Council, which hosted a Living Quilt event to commemorate National Black HIV/AIDS Awareness Day <ref name=state>Click, Carolyn. “HIV/AIDS Events highlight need for testing.” Feb. 5, 2008 <http://www.thestate.com/local/story/674747.html></ref> and state AIDS directors from Alabama, Georgia, Kentucky, Maryland, North Carolina, Virginia and Washington, D.C.
On May 13, 2009, the Living Quilt posted its 100th "patch," featuring Frances Ashe-Goins, Deputy Director of the Office on Women’s Health <ref name="Frances Ashe-Goins">Frances Ashe-Goins, Deputy Director of the Office on Women’s Health <http://www.womenshealth.gov/owh/about/nationalstaff/fashe-goins.cfm></ref> at the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]]. The milestone came as the nation recognized National Women's Health Week.<ref name="National Women's Health Week">National Women’s Health Week <http://www.womenshealth.gov/whw/></ref>
The Southern AIDS Living Quilt is a separate initiative from the [[NAMES Project AIDS Memorial Quilt]]. [[Southern United States|The South]] has the highest number of adults and adolescents living with AIDS in the U.S.<ref name=manifest>Southern AIDS Manifesto <http://www.southernaidscoalition.org/Manifesto%20Update%20Final%20pdf%20071408.pdf></ref>
HIV/AIDS has a disproportionate impact on African Americans compared with members of other races and ethnicities in the U.S.<ref name=cdc>CDC HIV/AIDS Factsheet <https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/topics/aa/resources/factsheets/pdf/aa.pdf></ref>
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=35em}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081201103321/http://livingquilt.org/ The Southern AIDS Living Quilt] * [http://www.southernaidscoalition.org/ Southern AIDS Coalition]
{{AIDS}}
